title-group.article-title: Suboptimal positioning of fragment-specific palmar distal radius plates

contrib.degrees: MA FRCS(Tr and Orth) BSSH Hand Diploma

contrib-group.aff: Department of Hand Surgery, Chelsea and Westminster Hospital, London, UK

permissions.copyright-holder: The British Society for Surgery of the Hand

body.p: There are a large variety of implant options available for the internal fixation of a distal radius fracture. As our understanding of fracture morphology and implant technology has advanced, plate designs have developed to accommodate fragment specific fixation. This precise fixed-angle screw positioning ensures the capture of fragments in the most common fracture configurations of the intermediate and radial ‘columns’ of the distal radius (Rikli and Regazzoni, 1996). The detailed design means that the plate can only be positioned within a limited footprint however, if it is to function correctly.

Surgical technique guides for the various implants are non-specific in their positioning advice, e.g. ‘Decide the correct position for the plate by judging how the plate conforms to the watershed line and the volar surface of the radius’ (Depuy, 2008); ‘after (the) fracture is reduced with Kirschner wires, apply the volar column plate to fit the volar surface’ (Synthes, 2010).

We have managed a number of cases where the plate was radially biased in its alignment, possibly in an effort to improve the perceived hold on the radial styloid, or through difficulty in reaching the palmar ulnar corner. Predictably, this leads to the loss of reduction of the ulnar column resulting in an unsatisfactory outcome.

A 40-year-old man sustained a distal radius fracture, had his fracture stabilized with a Synthes 2.4 mm volar column locking compression plate (LCP) (Figure 1) and was referred to us for further management once the palmar ulnar corner had malunited and the patient complained of a lack of supination (50° versus contralateral 82°). This was managed with a combination of ulna shortening osteotomy, distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ) release and excision of the bony block to supination at the palmar ulnar corner (Figure 2), with recovery of supination to 78° at seven months.

body.p: This case highlights an important, but frequently overlooked, detail of the fragment specific palmar distal radius plating technique. Not all implants are designed the same and it is vital that the surgeon understands how the chosen plate should be optimally positioned to allow the fixed-angle screws to have purchase in both columns of the distal radius. This will help to maintain the reduction, prevent the complications we have described and negate the need for complex corrective procedures with unpredictable outcomes (Lozano-Calderón et al., 2010).
